content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Marred by the same problem as the first Defense Grid: The difficulty is a rollercoaster. It alternates between stupid easy and stupid hard, usually based on map type. Some maps lets you build a tower maze, others don't. Some let you have a second crack at enemies as they try to escape with cores, others put their exit somewhere else. Some give you one avenue of attacks, others give you 2-4 enemy routes to defend against. And how difficult a given map is is entirely based on that.The even more frustrating part is enemies don't seem consistent. Some maps start with a horde of weak enemies that die instantly. One map later just 2 or 3 of what appear to be the same enemies will rush through your defense unphased. Could be different enemies, but most of them look the same in this game. The artist chose coherent enemy aesthetics over making distinct enemy types easily recognizable. Their movement patterns are the most distinct thing about them and most enemies adhere to just 3 types of movement: The normal walking speed, the crawling speed, and the rusher.Even within the same map, difficulty randomly jumps. Some waves are easy, some are nearly impossible. You'll go half the game not letting a single enemy by then get a wave of shielded aliens that run right past your Tesla (shield-destroying) Towers without blinking even if you have 4 fully upgrades, damage-boosted of the Tesla Towers specifically for peeling shielded aliens of their shields at the start of the enemy path.Like the first game, DG2 survives on one thing: Tower Defense is a dead genre. There is no competition. If you really crave a TD game better than a poor flash clone it'll be worth the money. But not by much.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												What is Defense Grid 2?Genre: tower defenseSetting: futuristic science fiction world gets attacked by aliensDifficulty: depends on difficulty level - everything from 2/10 to 10/10Length: 10 hours for a single campaign walkthrough, plus a lot more if interested in multiplayer and additional contentMode: singleplayer campaign and game modes, multiplayer The positive aspects:- Content monster! 20 campaign levels plus eight game modes plus a lot of additional DLC and community-made content make this game a long-time experience- easy to learn, well-timed introduction of new towers and their abilities- fair, but challenging difficulty levels- different defense towers with upgrades and special abilitiesThe negative aspects:- superficial story- texts are very very very small (by the means of it) and thus hard to read- towers and enemies could have had even more diversity Result (and summary for those who have no time reading):Defense Grid 2 is a real must-have when it comes to tower defense games. Don't hesitate to buy it, even at full price it is worth every penny (or cent, or whatever currency you pay with)!

												From the perspective of a newcomer to the series, I really enjoyed it! Good VO, a polished presentation, and the two levels available in Early Access were a lot of fun. content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												My reccommendation here is reluctant. Defense Grid 2 is certainly an improvement on Defense Grid, and it brings a lot of fun things to the table. However, There are significant issues plaguing the game on all fronts.Bugs render the game nearly unplayable in certain points. On a particular mission I found that building too many of one type of tower caused the game to crash consistently. Also, setting different resolutions using the launcher causes the game to behave strangely in different ways.The voice acting and writing is hammy and unbelievable. When you had the one robot talking to you in the first game, it was pleasant and even kind of funny: he set the mood really well. Suddenly, in Defense Grid 2 there are multiple AIs all interacting with each other in strange ways, and it's never really explained where they all come from. Their interaction makes the obviously forced and childishly-written dialog painful to the ears. Kudos to the game for making them unavailable when they're indisposed in the story though.The difficulties aren't calculated very well. Defense Grid was kind of hard! This game is pretty easy even when playing on hard difficulty. Honestly, the difficulty was what gave Defense Grid replay value, and after completing just the story mode in 2 I'm starting to get bored. All this aside, the game is very pretty. It's graphically superior to it's predecessor and the levels are designed really well. The addition of the different superweapons, command shuttle allowing you to spend resources to modify the placement environment, and the modified towers and gameplay are all very well implemented. All of the changes are simultaneously intuitive and graceful.

												Played the original game to death, and was worried reading some reviews that this wasn't going to be as much fun or in some way fundamentally flawed. In my opinion though, it is a worthy sequel - essentially the same old balance and mix of towers and aliens pretty much that made DG1 work so well, but with a few neat twists and upgrades to make the experienced DG player think. All seems highly polished, and absolutely loving the Steam Friend performance trackers as well. The only small negative I'd note is that the towers all look a bit too much the same this time round, but that really is a very minor point that doesn't affect the new enhanced gameplay. Most telling I think, is that I don't think I'd ever go back to DG1 now, which is high praise indeed from me. And I think I will also be playing *this* one to death. :)

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												A very weak thumbs-up, but a thumbs-up nonetheless.Defense Grid: The Awakening is probably the best standalone tower defense game ever made, so this sequel had huge shoes to fill. After a long saga of development including a failed Kickstarter campaign, the final result is something that improves upon the formula in some ways, but in other ways just made things much too confusing both for casual players and dedicated players alike. DG1's most memorable and perfect aspect was probably its scoring system. It was very simple: killing aliens awards resources, but you earn compound interest on your stored resources every few seconds, and your money basically becomes your score. Therefore, the tiniest change in strategy, especially at the beginning of the map, could result in an exponentially bigger score thanks to the accumulated compound interest. Despite its simplicity, aiming for high scores or even surviving the more difficult challenges was a ridiculously deep and complex experience, and hugely satisfying. In DG2, they scrapped this system altogether in favor of something more confusing that the game doesn't even take the time to explain. You don't earn compound interest anymore. Instead, you earn 10 free resources every few seconds, in addition to a fixed amount of resources after killing a wave of enemies. You earn points every time you kill an enemy, with (an arbitrary amount of) points awarded if you have more resources, and (an arbitrary amount of) less points awarded if you spent more money on towers. But it's needlessly confusing and the fandom is still not too sure how exactly it works and why playing more efficiently sometimes seems to result in a lower score. Plus, thanks to the orbital laser strike now awarding points, it's now possible to abuse the scoring system using some of the game's features, taking the game's focus away from tower placement and maze design.DG1's storytelling was minimalist, yet effective: at the beginning of each map, Fletcher would recite some lines which both characterized himself, hinted at the backstory, and explained the new game mechanics all at once. It was honestly compelling. In DG2, they threw about 6 AIs (and one human) together in the same room, and made them all drunk. At the beginning and end of every mission they spend upwards of five minutes rambling about desperately unfunny nonsense and leading up to a single, painfully predictable plot twist on the last level (the alien rune text even gives it away almost immediately!) The mission briefings can all be summarized as follows: "BLAH BLAH BLAH I LOVE THE MOOOOON!" "I know this sounds weird, but we really need to have a talk about raspberries." "Wow, isn't it weird how corrupted and single-minded we're all becoming? I wonder what's causing it?" "LOOK OUT, ALIENS INCOMING!" Needless to say, many people turn off the narration, and I don't blame them. At least the in-game banter is a bit more varied and interesting than in DG1, where Fletcher would whine about his cores every few seconds. Now they just sing the praises of boost towers.Boost towers are the only real new tower introduced in DG2, aside from the missile tower which now acts as a homing shot against ground units, due to flying mobs being completely removed. Boost towers act as a raised platform on which you can build any other tower type.  I started out thinking boost towers were annoying, but they really grew on me after a few missions: they allow cheap creation of mazes while saving gun choices for later, as well as allowing one of three special effects to a tower. There are also many new kinds of aliens, which is a welcome and expected addition.In DG1, each mission had about 10 extra modes, ranging from 99-wave challenges to 10-tower limit challenges. Getting a high score on a leaderboard was a hardcore task requiring some annoying skills like juggling, but you also had the choice of fixed-path maps or challenges with disabled interest, meaning you could choose a map or a mode where you don't have to juggle if you don't want to. Simple, elegant, straightforward.In DG2, they went with the "Everything and the kitchen sink" method of game balance. Not only do they have about 10 different game modes per map, but four difficulty levels, loadout perks for your towers, choice of about 7 effects for the orbital laser, and a "competitive" setting which disables loadout perks, and another one which disables selling of towers. That's a lot of options. But it makes it difficult to determine what modes and settings you *should* be using, especially if you intend to join the competetive scene, verses what modes you'll just be wasting your time with. It seems like the designers said "it's too much work to balance the game, here's hundreds of play modes per level, go balance the game yourself." Options are great, but this is confusing and overwhelming, especially since the actual gameplay itself -- the design and pacing of the enemy waves -- seems a bit rushed and not so well thought-out.DG2 is beautiful. The graphics are a great improvement to the original game, and the in-game HUD is amazing, even showing a miniature score ticker so you can measure your performance against previous attempts in real time. However, the main menu is a disastrous and confusing pile of options that's non-intuitive and designed primarily for a controller. Plus all the options reset themselves whenever you choose a new game mode, making it a bit frustrating and intimidating just to start a game the way you want. More than once I've selected the wrong mode or the wrong difficulty, just because changing some options will change other options without telling you.D♥♥♥♥dds a some truly interesting co-op and competitive multiplayer, including modes with shared and separate scores and resource pools. However, the checkpoint and fast-forward features are unavailable during co-op, meaning that playing a Grinder mission with a friend will literally take an hour.Speaking of the fast-forward feature, it was broken in DG1 -- using it at any time could alter fate, as it created fuzzy and non-deterministic estimations of future events. Meteor towers randomly wouldn't strike their targets, temporal towers wouldn't pulse at the same time, and towers in general would choose to target different enemies than before. Hoping this was fixed in DG2? It's not. In fact, it got worse.DG1 had a staggering number of DLC and map packs to play. Six campaigns in total, including the original campaign, and a Portal cross-over. DG2 has nothing. Sure, you can make and share your own maps with the community, but it doesn't use Steam workshop. Instead, you have to download them from third-party sites, and some even cost money. Um... what? I actually thought that it was against Steam's terms of service for a game to redirect you to a third-party site for paid DLC where you can't use your Steam Wallet funds. Isn't this why EA got Dragon Age II and some of its other games kicked off of Steam?Overall, despite its many steps in the wrong direction, DG2 is worthy of playing for any fan of DG1, especially if you were really hungering for online co-op. Good graphics, good maps, good new features and ideas. Just don't go into it expecting the best Tower Defense experience ever, or something that can replace its predecessor. Instead, try to see it for what it is: a complement to the original game, something like one final glorious expansion set to Defense Grid: The Awakening, and remember that you can always return to the original game whenever you want.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												If you’re unfamiliar with Defense Grid, its biggest hook in the tower defense world is one that can be explained fairly easily. As you play, certain stages have levels with open grids on them for tower placement. The creeps, those are the aliens trying to steal your cores and take them back, will alter their paths based on your tower placement.So, there’s a strategy in placing towers in specific spots rather than just plopping each gun down and upgrading to win. Now, I don’t think Defense Grid was the first to do this, but I do think it does it exceptionally well. Each level that has these open layouts is much more interesting and challenging than others, and command centers on the levels will let you annex new regions in order to push out the length of the creeps’ path.You’re not only playing with your budget in order to come up with the best defense power, but you’re trying to lay out towers and boost blocks (basically, a tower upgrade spot that brings better stats to your big guns later in each level) so that you can do the most damage on creeps during their runs.What’s frustrating about this game is that it’s impossible to have a planning phase. The levels start without you saying so, so you won’t be able to look at the map and decide which path is best before you start laying towers. Especially in the later game, the creeps move too fast and are far too strong for you to sit around and plan tower placement. I found this tough to contend with, especially since I’m the type of player who can’t play through tower defense games without getting perfect scores.I like the dynamic paths and forcing creep behavior, I just wish the game would give me an option to pause and look at the map before it steals all my cores and causes me to lose.  That’s probably just the perfectionist in me, though.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												I kickstarted this game, and played it the first day in alpha.  The game had an enormous stuttering problem on my medium-high spec PC.  The game freezes for a good quarter of a second every single second, making it basically unplayable. I reported this on the very first day.Fast forward two years later, and nothing has changed.  The stuttering is still horrible on that PC.About a month ago, I upgraded to an ultra-high spec PC, using all the top gaming hardware available at the time:* Intel i7 6700K, 4.4Ghz OC* NVidia GTX 980 TI* 32GB Rametc.I tried out Defense Grid 2, and it still freakin' stutters.  The stuttering only lasts about 1/10th of a second now, making the game playable, but it still happens every damn second.  I couldn't stand to play more than one level.If they still haven't fixed the issue after all this time, they never will.EDIT: It looks like instead of fixing this debilitating issue, they were busy adding microtransactions.  Wow.  I will never buy (and certainly never kickstart) another game from Hidden Path Entertainment.EDIT 2: Finally tried out the multiplayer with a friend (despite the stuttering still existing).  Looks like the game's highly-touted "multiplayer campaign" is actually just single-player with two cursors.  It's ridiculously boring.  Did they not test this at all?

												(08/10) - SuperbIt is finally back!Not as good as hoped but better than expected...So yes, the dialogs inbetween (and more often than not even inside) the levels can be quite broing, some visuals (like walkpath of the aliens) are very hard to see and they removed the layer of air units/defenses but overall, DG2 is what it does best, a tower defense game. And the best one in existance for that matter.Perfect balancing, extremly interesting maps, an amazing mix between standart TD and maze TD and so much tower and enemy variety, that it can easily crush all competitors in the TD genre.One thing tho, that really bugged me:I was happy to see more difficulties (which are extremly challenging), but grinding for tower items should never be the way. It would be 9 points, but like this, i can only give 8.Still an absolutly amazing game..

												If you want a coop TD game, to play casually with someone, this game is great! :)Mind these cons, though:- Map editor is one of the most UNFRIENDLY editors ever made. I do not recommend this game if you want it for its map editor.- After each map, your reward is RANDOM (one of your towers gets an improvment, from lvl 1 to 5), and if you manage to get a lvl 5 tower early on, you may be able to finish all maps using only that tower, because it gets so OP that you strategy matters less than firepower.Even so, this is a game that can be enjoyed by "hardcore" and casual gamers alike - if it gets too easy, try a versus match, where things get chaotic ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Best TD title is back and hitting hard! I must say I had my doubts, before I saw it in action on my own screen. If you have or haven't experienced DG1, this is a must buy. Many things have changed for better or worse, but still more coud've been done. Graphics are pretty much the same, but explosions got a major bloom/flare treatment that would make J.Lo burn her A cup. Script and specially voice acting are top notch and often absolutely hilarious.There are plenty of levels to explore, replay value with multiple game modes and difficulties. By the looks of it, we'll be getting more levels in near future made by community and developers. I just hate the fact that they ask money for average designs already. Only real problem that I complain is a dodgy difficulty. It is showing it's ugly face very clearly on competitive mode. There you won't be able to use AI bonus/tower perk tricks and even on normal you will run into a wall of W.T.F moments, a lot.Once you are getting used to a single player content, there is an option for challenging multiplay, either co-op or against. Shame that there is no option for speeding up the game (co-op 24.9.14), so combat often feels like watching a paint dry. If you're playing with a random player, shared resources mean that a person with a faster metabolism steam rolls.DG2 has a lot of shells for a boomstick. Even that we are getting near perfection, I would've hoped for a little more tuning before release. Thinking about some sort of rpg elements and programmable towers? Those darn towers sometimes just shoot the wrong targets! Anyway, to me this is worth every penny and if you purchased DG2 in beta you got a pile of extra stuff. That nice little copy of DG1 to give to your friend, -50% ticket for Windborne (which looks really promising) and more. Hidden Path Entertainment, you have done it!9,5/10Money value: Insert your coins here!p.s. Some of the leaderboards seem to be infected by cheaters...

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												tl;dr: It's just as addictive as the original Defense Grid.I've played 83 hours of the original Defense Grid. No, it did not have 83 hours of content, but with the original campaign and several DLC packs we were given room to play with. And tweak, fiddle and generally mess around with what was possible. With all the different game modes, you could play each map dozens of times. DG2 gives us all that and more.What's different? - Shiny new graphics! More voiceover artists! New aliens!The only "new" tower is the Boost Tower, which goes under other towers. This makes whatever you build on top taller, and you can spend resources to activate a Boost Tower special ability: 25% damage bonus, cloak disruptor, score enhancement, etc. This makes command towers obsolete.The other tower change is the missile tower, which now also shoots ground targets.There's been some tweaking in the damage outputs, so that guns aren't always the most efficient option.Is it worth the price? - I was a little unsure about $25, but I've been totally sucked in by DG2. Music, graphics, gameplay are all great. There's even a plot this time. So yes, it's worth it.

content:
Posted: January 14
												DG1 was one of the best tower defense games of all time.  DG2 is a worthy follow-up to that game.  DG2 does, of course, have better graphics.  All of the maps are well designed and extremely fun.  And, like DG1, this game has plenty of alternate play modes, such as Frozen Core, Out Of Bullets, SuperGrinder, etc.  This installment also introduces Boost towers that can give second row towers better line-of-sight, and which also amp up your towers with added abilities like extra damage, enemy shield disruption, etc.  However, DG2 seemed a lot easier to me.  I mean, I can play SuperGrinder on "Elite" difficulty setting and still get a gold medal on the level without breaking much of a sweat.  Also, there isn't as many maps that come with the game, so the game felt shorter to me than DG1.  Still, overall, it's a phenomenally good game just like its predecessor.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												If you are a fan of Tower Defense games, DG2 is a perfectly fine example of the genre, and certainly worth playing.  That being said, this is not a game you are likely to fall in love with.(Note: unlike most reviewers, I never played the first Defense Grid; in other words, I'll just be reviewing this game as it stands, not as it compares to another game.)DG2 is a pretty standard tower defense game, and a reasonably well done one at that.  There is an interesting variety of towers, enemies, and maps.  Different maps can be defeated in different ways.  It does a good job of ramping up the difficulty slowly, and introducing new towers and enemy types in a way that new players don't feel overwhelmed.  In other words, it's just about everything that you'd say you want in a tower defense game.  The campaign has an okay plot--at times it was amusing, and I was intrigued at first, though the ending was a bit abrupt.  With 20 maps in the campaign, it's a reasonable length--a bit on the short side, perhaps, but not bad.That being said, while it does nothing wrong, it doesn't particularly shine in any given area either.  It's average or slightly above average tower defense game in basically every respect.  The most original thing here is the fact that you can control enemy pathing on certain maps with your tower placement; a fine addition, but only a few of the maps really take advantage of that feature.  Otherwise, I've seen this all before; occasionally done better, often done worse, but I could never quite shake the "been there, done that" feeling.If you like the genre, by all means play DG2.  You'll certainly get your money's worth.  Just temper your expectations a bit.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												"DG2" is an excellent successor to "Defense Grid." The game balance has been changed to reward educated experimentation over "trial-error-rollback-repeat," and it also feels like each map can be done well in more than one way. The continuous resource accumulation helps to eliminate some of the more punishing aspects of the first game. With tower-currency flowing in steadily, it's much more possible to recover from mistakes."Defense Grid 2" certainly feels more expansive than its predecessor, with a larger number of tower pads to build on and a much more viable long-range game. I would even go so far as to say that a major key to the experience is getting strong use out of missile and meteor towers: You'll definitely want their ability to keep delivering damage over a large surface area.The game's pacing has also been tweaked. "Defense Grid" sometimes felt ponderous, even if that ponderousness was also coupled with desperation. "DG2," on the other hand, seems to manage to keep events rolling at a nice clip without constantly overwhelming the player.What it all amounts to is a smartly balanced experience that keeps the player returning. It's amazing to look up at the time counter and realize that a 20+ minute map has just flown by. The banter between the various AI personalities is also done very well, and flavors the action nicely with humor, drama, and a really good bit of mystery. Hidden Path has definitely crafted another gem.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												As being a hugh fan of DG, I had to buy the second one too.The game has improved in many ways. The graphics are good and the new path display is very helpful in planning your towers. I also like the points display at the top right, where you can see how well you are doing for points. (That's if you are in the highscore gathering league, which I think is the most exciting thing about DG)Overall the game feels similar to the first one. I am sure the campaign will be great, since the Devs have done a great job with the first game and it's DLCs.I don't like the new music that much and would really like to see/hear the old music again. Maybe that could be as an option under the sound options?The tower design is good, although I would like to have them a little more different and easier to seperate. Once the map is more busy, it's a little difficult the identy what is what!Summary: If you liked the first game, you will definately like this one too! Can't wait to have the full game available and play the campaign!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												In a few words:This is the best small developer (see: indie) tower defense game out there.  There is always a debate in some communities if this game is "better" than the DG1.  For my money, DG2 is a fantastic game with more modes and better options than DG1.If you aren't familiar with the Defense Grid 1 there is nothing wrong with picking up this one and then going back and playing DG1.  DG2 just feels more complete as a game.In a few more words:This is a tower defense game.  You, as the player (or commander as they call it) build various mechanisms (aka towers) to stop aliens from stealing your resources.  If you lose all your resources, game over.Each map typically has aliens march along predetermined paths in their never ceasing quest to steal your energy cores.  Along this path are build points in which the player erects towers of various designs (missiles, guns, lasers, etc) to eliminate the aliens and move on to the next map.The goal is almost always to destroy all the aliens but the player is challenged to not only win, but build effciently in order to boost their score.  Towers can be upgraded and the player is awarded with bonuses and upgrades at various points in the game.There are multiple modes outside of the main story campaign.  They typically involve some type of special challenge or limitation.  The bottom line:This is a great game and its a nice way to kill time when you are bored with more traditional strategy games.  I highly recommend it for tower defense fans and first timers who are interested in something a little different.Final Grade: B+

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
((Recommended, but quite a reserved one.  And only if you really enjoyed DG1 and go in to this with lowered expectations))Defense Grid 2 shows a number of changes, but only a couple of those changes were for the better.The Good:+ It's still a good Tower Defense game.  (Just not a great one any more).+ Graphics and the rotatable view.+ Fly-overs showing overview of mission map.+ Ability to show the path the aliens will take.The Eh:~ A GRAPH of my score during gameplay?  OK.  Why?~ Mission medal awarded solely on mission score; regardless of # of cores lost.~ Boost Towers?  Needless complication / addition to game...~ "Normal" difficulty seems easier than DG1.  Either I'm MUCH better than I was when I played DG1, but I received GOLD on every mission with only have to restart or go to an earlier checkpoint on a couple missions in the campaign.  In DG1, um, I am proud of the few gold medals I did earn in my first play through.~ Large size of some maps, changes the 'feel of the game'.~ Why all the different types of orbital lasers now?~ "Heat Map" of where you caused the most dmg to aliens.  OK, it's "pretty" but you already know where you cause the most dmg.The Bad:- The Radar in DG1 showing the upcoming alien types I liked SO MUCH better than what they did in DG2.- Voice Acting.  OMG.  Voice acting is not just bad, it's truly awful!  The returning voice of General Fletcher is good, Cai's delivery was OK (until the dialog turned cringe-worthy), but the rest were terrible regardless of the dialog.- The post-mission banter/story by the voice actors / AI's (and even DURING a mission) is horrible.- The complete gibberish at the start of a level shown by alien/encrypted text giving another viewpoint of the story.  Just nonsense.- More confusing game menus and pre-mission tower configurations/upgrades, given no explanation.- Missile Towers remain, but no flying aliens in DG2??- Level design is not as varied as DG1.  Larger maps, but generally 1 way in, and 1 way out.- Rank removed from mission summary?  I loved that feature of DG1!  Though you can browse the leaderboard to (slowly) determine your rank after a mission, you have to go looking for it.Summary:Defense Grid 2 while still enjoyable, is not nearly so much so as DG1.  Quite a let down.  7.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Horrible game. Got it for Multiplayer. It *MIGHT* be viable for single player gameplay but its multiplayer is the worst piece of crap I have Ever experienced. It's obvious that this game was designed for single player and added in multiplayer as an after thought. Not only after a story multiplayer mission does it not continue the story, your only two options are to exit and recreate a lobby to select the Next mission or go back to select the Next Mission Anyway rather than the typical "Continue" type mechanic. What the hell type of thinking is this?There's no reason to play Multiplayer. None. Nothing. You share resources in multiplayer. They are Completely shared. It turns into two different people creating something together to one person directing where things go and the 2nd player sitting along for the ride. It is Ridiculous. The towers are horrible and boring. The first three are a standard machine gun tower, an inferno AoE one, and a cannon that trumps all in damage regardless of AoE or single target.The UI itself is horrible, there's no sort of obvious hotkey system which makes you Repeatedly go into your setting just to look them up. The tutorial is basic at best and gives you almost no information. Nothing about the heat map, etc. In multiplayer they STILL give you a Single Player tutorial regardless of your mode. For example the tooltips still pop up for the Fast Forward feature which is a Single Player only option. This is lazy game designing and should be marketed as a single player game. It *might* be decent in the single player aspect but I Still find the gameplay itself boring and horrendous. There was a CLEAR lack of effort in this god awful game and I strongly urge ANYONE looking to purchase this to rethink their decision. With quality like this you're Much better off investing in a different game or saving your money.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												With a campaign, multiplayer, co-op and user generated content (through the Steam Workshop integration), Defense Grid 2 has a ton of content that will give any strategy fan hours of entertainment.


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Defense Grid 2' 

			Views: 29		

			PD recommends Cheap Games here: https://www♥♥♥♥♥com/r/paradisedecay I take a quick look @ 'Defense Grid 2' If you ever only play 1 tower defense game in your life..... this is the one!		

Having not played the original I approached this as just another tower defense game and I have to admit I was pleasantly surprised. It's a good looking game with some great map design, a nice variety of enemies and nice selection of towers and upgrade paths. I did find it was a bit system intensive and occassionally a bit buggy, and it could have maybe done with a little more time spent on the optimisation rather than graphics. I'm also not a huge fan of the plot (and find the necessity to include a storyline in a tower defense game a little superfluous if I'm honest), and the voice acting gets a little grating, but I can appreciate the developers attempt to tie each of the levels together and push you through the campaign.At it's current price of about £18 it may be one for just the die hard fans but as time goes on and more maps are created (and if the price drops a little) I definitely think its worth picking up whether you're a hardcore strategist after the highest score possible or you want something little more casual you can dip in and out of. I can certainly see myself returning and sinking hours into this game, trying to find the most efficient way of slaughtering hordes of alien scum.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												DG2. Finally!(Being a die-hard DG fan, I have been waiting a long time for thisfor this.Since I have only tried the early access version, having only two levels avaliable it was quickly over. But it did not disappoint. Only two where available for early access. And I want to play it a lot more).Anyway, playing the game is a familiar feeling for a DG fan. It looks the same, sounds the same and plays almost the same. There are a few new addons that potentially can completely change the flow of the map. Take the platform, that you build and then place a tower on it, adding height and range.This can change and extend the kill zone or giving a previous unusable spot a potential tower.Also the maps are no longer static. One level was transformed after about 30% of the waves had passed, adding a lot more room, and changed the layout and the entire planning of the map.Well, since it is still early access it's hard to say what the final product may be, but what I have tried I really like. they improved the game, carefully adding features that adds more interesting gameplay without hurting the things that made DG so good. You can still micromanage and OCD about the perfect route, and each map have many additional modes to play, adding tons of replay value.In short: Love it. I truly recommend it!

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												There is too much Tower Defense in the world.  It started with just two, but some idiot programmer left them alone in a room full of green M&Ms and thus was born an army of annoying little TD anklebiters.  Greatness languished as an extremely recessive gene in this motley genre of mostly half-baked look-alikes, biding its time until it could express itself in the Chosen One and light a path for forlorn strategy gamers the world over.That Chosen One was Defense Grid, the only AAA Tower Defense.  This game is a worthy heir to the Chosen One, carrying on a tradition of unlikely greatness.  Someday, the heir might even surpass the Chosen One.  Only time will tell.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												DG1 is the best tower defense game out there, hands down.  This doesn't quite live up to its predecessor unfortunately.The Bad:The UI / Menu system is horrendous (outside of the gameplay itself).  Too much going on and the "continue" buttons could be in the center of the screen on one menu, then lower right on the next, then the upper left.  It's also not easy to distinguish what should be grabbing your focus to continue on any given menu.The towers and monsters have lost a lot of their visual uniqueness.  I'm not sure if it's because the monsters are smaller (larger overall maps?) or what but most of the time you won't tell one monster from another.  I'm not sure what it is about the towers.  They are incredibly detailed when zoomed in but when zoomed out that detail kind of obscures what the tower is compared to different towers.The story is...not great.  Not sure why they needed to add a ton of new A.I. characters but for the most part I didn't feel they added anything (plus it was easy lose track of who was who).The good:It, for the most part, still plays like DG1 and is a fun tower defense game

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Defense Grid 2 is a typical Tower Defense game. The Gameplay is like Defense Grid The Awakening - anyone who has played that, will immediately feel at home.This time there are no flying aliens. While you're playing through the game, you unlock selectable perks for the towers (Laser slows target; Cannon does aoe damage in a 5 degree cone, Inferno does more single target damage etc). Additionally, towers can be built on boost blocks giving them special abilities (more damage; decloaking; increased score etc).The story is a bit too confusing - very quickly I was lost even at the quite simple question who of those bunch of voices is supposed to be an AI and who not. The Level intro texts donn't help much, because they seem to be telling a completely different story at first.In the top right corner you can see how you are doing in comparison to your friends during every step of the level.There are many modes for the levels that add quite some replayability.If you just want to play the levels once, you'll be done with this in ~12-15hours. There is also a level editor integrated.Thumbs up for TD :D

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Defense Grid: The Awakening was one of my favourite strategy games ever, if I dare say so. Opposite to many RTS and also Tower Defense games that come out today, it required thinking, strategical placement, spamming one tower rarely got you anywhere and if it did, the score would be far too low to compete with your friends, let alone the leaderboard. Add the flair of Raspberry-Fetishist Fletcher's voice, and it was one of the most fun games to play while still producing a challenge.DG2 had the difficult job of following that up. After playing through the campaign, I am happy to say that it does so flawlessly. The Story connects to the Add-On "Containment" and thanks to excellent voice acting lets you sympathize even with AIs. And for Fans of the first game, it has one of the biggest twists you can imagine.But where the game shines is gameplay. If you're new to Tower Defense games, play on lower difficulties, ease into it, learn placement and what tower to chose in what situation, about forming paths and defending the cores bit by bit, and if you fail, one button is enough for a return to the last checkpoint. It's the simplicity that helps. However, advanced TD gamers will find the harder difficulties a challenge, especially if you want to compete scorewise. It's a dance on a razors edge, one mistake early in the game can lead to total failure 20 minutes later. The new elements like the Boost tower (which is just a base that lets you control line of sight and boosts tower on top of it)  integrate perfectly with all the towers and aliens we know from Part 1. Most towers have been well redesigned, the only one I don't like is the cannon tower. The old Triple-Cannon which seemed like taken directly from a Battleship gave the tower a sense of might, as where the new one looks more like the pneumatic experiment of a sixth grader that shoots  shells by compressing air *cough* which is too bad because if well placed, it's an essential part of any strategy especially later in the game. I'm also not quite sure about the "Recieve ressources in ticks rather than interest" thing, holding off spending your cash until the last moment was an integral thing for competing for highscores, waiting a few seconds before placing a tower could mean the difference between just some score or an attack on the Top 10. Time will tell if the new system holds the same competitiveness.If you loved DG1, I can wholeheartedly suggest DG2 to you. You'll find everything you liked about the first part, overhauled and redesigned, with several new elements added that can create a new challenge you first have to develop a working strategy to (Took me some time to get the hang about dealing with the tower disabling alien even on lower difficulties), and of course we got Fletcher back who alone is worth this game. If you're new to Tower Defense, DG is the perfect brand to start, it won't overwhelm you directly, but you have to use your brain or the aliens will be out the door with all the cores before you figured out how to upgrade your towers.And for long term fun, there's DG Architect, the map creator, which is included. I'm very much looking forward to finding some of the challenges the Steam Community builds. And of course just kicking some more alien behind is always fun ;)

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												This game is everything that a tower defence should be. In fact, it may become the standard by which other tower defence games are judged. If I had to pick one feature that sets it apart it is the ability to correct a misplaced tower with the backspace key instead of having to restart the level. The number of different ways in which every level can be played offers the promise of hundreds of hours of unalloyed gaming pleasure.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Defense Grid 2 is a good tower defense game, but not the best. The best is still the first game, Defense Grid: The Awakening. If you've played the first game, they have basically improved the graphics and added/tweaked some things (not necessarily for the better). If you haven't played the first game, buy that instead. It's a much, much better game, with much higher replayability and a lot more levels.The main differences in DG2:- Instead of command towers you now have boost towers. They end up being a bit of a resource burden since not using a boost tower is always worse than using one and you can't go back and add one later. They are useful to cheaply control the path of aliens though.- Flying enemies have been removed, although missile towers remain and now fill the same role as meteor towers.- You can sometimes alter the terrain and create new build areas, although this feature wasn't explained and I didn't learn about it until almost finishing the game. It is not actually needed to succeed, so kind of pointless.- Towers now have passive upgrade items of different rarities, and at the start of a mission you can choose which one to have for each tower. You randomly unlock them after finishing a mission. They slightly alter the way towers behave, for example making lasers slow down foes, making guns pierce shields or making cannons damage multiple enemies. They come in different levels, so eventually you can have quite overpowered towers and these are needed for playing on higher difficulties.- There is now a level editor and people can sell their levels via Steam Workshop.- There are now some multiplayer modes, which I haven't tried yet so can't comment on, however the co-operative mode in which you share resources seems pointless. Considering you normally know where you want to put your towers, I'm not sure how having another player placing them would ever be helpful. Seems like it would only make things harder. The other multiplayer modes might be more worthwhile.- There are now alternatives to the orbital laser that you unlock as you go along. These are quite useful and suit different playstyles (e.g. slowing aliens, giving you some free resources).- Tower balance: from what I remember of the first game it has been tweaked somewhat. It's not so reliant on guns and cannons, while other towers like lasers and concussion are more valuable.- Scoring: they have changed how scoring works and the game also feels easier (I got gold on every mission very easily). The scoring seems more focused on killing aliens as fast as possible, whereas the first game involved more careful resource management to get big scores and you had to be more careful about when you built towers if you wanted to earn the most interest. The scoring seems much more variable now and less precise. However, a recent patch added the ability to play with the old scoring style. It also shows you your score on a graph while playing, with someone on your friend's list to compare with, which is a really nice feature.I found the campaign to be a bit short, the voice acting is very annoying and distracting and continues for too long after you finish a level, and the story is bad (although I guess in this kind of game that doesn't matter). But the game is also not challenging or compelling. Replaying levels in different modes is boring.Ultimately this is a fun game, but they have lost the perfect formula that made the first game so addictive and replayable. DG2's biggest fault is that it is not DG1.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												This sequel to Defense Grid feels very natural on a console controller. I noticed a complaint in another review which is true: the towers are hard to tell apart zoomed all the way out. I think the reason is that the farthest zoom level is for a map overview.The zoom levels are very easy to control in that there are three zoom levels, not a gradual scroll-wheel style zoom. It very much seems like this was developed for console controls, which is perfectly fine for me, but may frustrate people who want to play on a keyboard and mouse.While speed up on toggle instead of press may seem like an odd change (it's optional, but it's the default setting), it seems more natural once you've adjusted to it.Resource points advance with time, but also on wave completion, not on kill.If you liked Defense Grid, and you're not allergic to console controls and a nice comfy couch, DG2 is a huge recommend+.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I do not feel like a tower defense game should have been very hard to make a sequel for. Defense Grid: The Awakening was  the first successful retail tower game that I can remember, and it did everything well. There was a great difficulty curve, and there was a lot of replayability.Somehow, the developers took everything the first Defense Grid had, made it just a little bit worse, and released it as a sequel. I can not really put my finger on why, but I did not enjoy this one as much as the first game.The humor is a big miss, and the dialogue is far more annoying than entertaining. Instead of one AI commentating, there is a squad of them bantering back and forth, and very quickly it becomes more noisy than interesting. The AI also seem to enjoy talking for awhile after you finish a mission, either delaying you or forcing you to miss the story to get some more gameplay.The game is much easier than the first one, and very few maps gave me any trouble. It is seemingly impossible to play through on hard for your first time, though, because you need to upgrade your towers with rare drops. The main campaign missions don't last long, and I didn't feel an urge to play the side missions.I still had a good time with the game, but it is a disappointing sequel to one of the best tower defense games ever. If you're craving more Defense Grid, it can't hurt to pick up for a lower price, but it definitely leaves something to be desired.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												This review will speak to those who played and enjoyed Defense Grid 1.The graphics have been made prettier, but I find this was not required. The original game was fine enough.The towers are ever so slightly different. A missile tower exists now aiming down instead of up, though it seems redundant with the meteor tower. No flying enemies yet 8 waves into the game.The menus are more confusing and seem more optimized for console play. No more independent mouse cursor, your mouse is locked to moving your entire view around. No clicking on any button-looking screen decoration; you have no mouse.The levels are challenging and fun, definitely worthy additions to the existing Defense Grid database of fun puzzles.PROBLEM: The voice acting and script writing has gone down tremendously in quality. The Commander character in particular feels like a pubescent boy constantly yelling in the mic, existing only to keep repeating the same message to the player. The elder British commander, while once being a lone, tragic figure, is now just a surly, self-confident boob. The female AI characters are both shallow farces of characters, used for scornful comic relief or suspicion. Worst of all, since there's a zoo of AI's with you at all times, you are constantly treated to this circus of immature jokes and rather light-hearted treatment of a vital threat to humanity.In the original game, you and the AI formed a bond. You got through this together. Now? You're the only one doing hard work while the AI's bicker, insult each other, and generally provide nothing of use.So, buy it for the puzzles and great gameplay, but you might actually enjoy the game better on Mute with some techno playing. All the important bits of the plot are found between levels in the decoded alien script. Use your imagination, and spare yourself the Five Stooges uploaded into AI form.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												What is Defense Grid 2?A Tower Defence game in the traditional format. Aliens spawn from one or more locations in progressively harder waves, move towards your base, steal power cores, and attempt to escape. The player has to stop them by spending limited resource points to place towers such as lasers and flamethrowers, in specific build locations around the map.Is it any good?Absolutely. Tower Defence has become one of my favourite genres, I've had alot of fun with the original Defense Grid (Steam tells me I've played it for 84 hours) and several other games, so I was expecting to enjoy D♥♥♥♥nd it has not let me down.What pleased me?•	Level design. There's a nice mixture of narrow paths, wide open plazas where you can build a maze, and multiple paths that force you to split resources.•	New types of aliens. One can regenerate health when not taking damage, another gives off an EMP that temporarily disables nearby towers when it dies, and there's also a dropship that lands next to your base and spawns a bunch of other aliens.•	Tower loadouts. There aren't many new towers, but each tower can unlock new special abilities that are equipped pre-mission. For example, lasers can slow down the targeted alien, teslas can disable an alien's stealth ability, and several other towers can automatically prioritise the strongest alien in range.•	Orbital laser has alternate modes, such as shooting towers to overcharge them and do more damage for a short time, or shooting loose cores to teleport them back to base.•	All of the above points result in lots of tactical depth and variety.•	Value for money. There are 20 maps, they all have multiple alternate challenge modes, and 4 difficulty levels. You can potentially spend dozens of hours trying to achieve a gold medal on each one.•	Your current score is displayed while playing, which is really useful to see how close you are to earning a medal.•	Stability. I've only suffered 1 crash in 10 hours, and the developers have just released a patch which should fix the most common crash reasons.What disappointed me?•	The story is nonsensical gibberish and voice acting is poor. However, I don't think Tower Defence games need to be strong in this area, so its not a big problem.Overall recommendationIf you like Tower Defence, buy D♥♥♥♥t full price. If you've never played the genre, DG2 would be a good game to start with. I don't think its essential to play the first game to enjoy the sequel.

												I know this has been out for awhile, but I recent;y picked it up and decided to give it a try. I really enjoy Tower Defense games, and Defense Grid 1 was great. Defense Grid 2, seems to be a worthy successor with a few upgraded aliens, some new graphics, good sound, excellent writing, superb voice acting, well balanced maps, and some neat tower upgrades. I've seen reviews that say it's just a re-hash of the first one, and I guess about 90% of the gameplay is the same, but that sure didn't douse my enthusiasm or diminish the fun I've had playing the first 10 levels of the campaign. In short, if you liked the first one, this is a worthy successor. If you haven't played the first one and you're not sure you want to plop down the cash, go try Defense Grid 1 out first. It's a cheaper investment and you can catch up on the story before sitting down in the middle of this one.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Note: this review is mostly from the PS4 version of the game, which I also own and prefer to play because my Notebook can't handle the PC version very well.  They're the same game, but I've played that one more.  I clarify this because I only have 1 hour clocked on the PC version, and I don't want to give the impression that I haven't played it enough.The original Defense Grid is one of the best Tower Defense games in existence.  Heck, it probably is THE best.  Incredibly fun and addictive (in a good way), with a lot of content, varied gameplay and clearly coming from a group of developers who care for their audience and know how to make fun games (as evidenced by the minigames they created for the Portal 2 ARG).At first sight, this sequel looks to be the same.  A fantastic entry in the genre with the same basic gameplay and enough upgrades to justify it being a sequel rather than just DLC.  There are new tower types and upgrades, new enemies, new special weapons (the original had only one), a new story and lots of new characters.  There are also new modes to play (with advantages or handicaps) and extra abilities that can be setup before starting each stage.  In short, there's A LOT of content here.But, it's an impossible to ignore fact that, when compared to the first game, this one is still inferior.  And this is mostly because of a couple of factors: freedom and balance.  The original game pretty much allowed you to play however you wanted.  It gave you a lot of freedom on how to approach each stage.  This one, though, requires certain stages to be played an exact way if you intend to finish it with a decent score.  This issue causes the second one, as there's a couple of ridiculous difficulty spikes, as in a few stages the game forces you to change your playstyle to something specific if you want to have any chance.  Now you're basically following orders rather than playing for fun.To be fair, if you don't care at all about getting medals or keeping all the cores at the end then the difficulty is not a problem.  This is a very easy game in that respect.  Much easier than the first one, actually (there aren't even flying aliens here).  But if you do care for a question of completionism, challenge or achievement hunting, you're going to have a lot of frustration and you'll probably be forced to look for walkthroughs (something that rarely if ever happened on the first game).In short, it's still a good game.  Great even if your expectations for gameplay end with "being able to advance to the next stage".  But it's still an undeniably inferior product to the original in aspects that are quite important for this genre.7/10

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I'll keep this review short and sweet.  If you like Tower Defense games, and if you liked the original Defense Grid, then you should *definitely* pick up DG2!  The graphics are slightly better than the first Defense Grid, but the excellent gameplay and mechanics have returned and have also been refined and enhanced.  One of DG2's greatest strengths is its level design.  Now the levels are bigger and better, but more importantly, they evolve and that changes up the gameplay considerably (in a good way).  D♥♥♥♥lso features some online multiplayer and co-operative gameplay which will appeal to those who love multiplayer strategy games.  The core of the game still revolves around buying, placing, and upgrading towers, but DG2 takes the classic formula and almost perfects it.  The story and narrative is interesting but of course it comes secondary to the mechanics and the overall polish found in the implementation of DG2's features and it's slick and easy to use inteface.  It's a little more expensive than the original Defense Grid when it first came out, but if you're enjoy the genre and loved the prequel, then you'll love DG2.  The $24.99 price tag is steep if you're a casual gamer or casual TD player, but the increased cost is well worth it if you consider the extra gameplay and replay value to be had from DG2's multiplayer modes and the inclusion of a level editor and Steam Workshop support.  On top of all of that, Steam achievements and online statistics make a return from the first game with even more detailed info that will allow you to compare scores and compete with your friends or other players from around the world.  So if you're a casual player of the genre, I'd recommend waiting for a sale or a slight price drop.  Everyone else who likes sinking their teeth into a good Strategy game or Tower Defense, and those who also like multiplayer modes in those genres, look no further - because DG2 will keep you entertained and occupied for quite some time.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												People kept telling me, "Defense Grid is the greatest TD of all time."I looked at the videos and I was like, "Well, it looks good."I looked at the price tag and I was like, "♥♥♥♥ that♥♥♥♥♥♥" and I marked it 'Not Interested'.Then yet another person was telling me how awesome it is, and I looked in and saw it on sale for $7. So I bought it and I'm sitting here playing it. I'm already about 1/4 the way through, and it's the exact same game as all other standard TD games. I mean seriously. Same tower types, same enemy types (except the cloaking enemy), same general strategy.So I mean... It's not a bad game, but for ♥♥♥♥'s sake, $25? That's just too much for a generic TD. I mean the only advantage here is flashy 3D graphics and voice acting. I ♥♥♥♥ing hate flashy 3D graphics and voice acting when all they accomplish is jacking up the price.So anyway, I'm not really mad that I paid $7 for it, but I'm not going to recommend it either. $25 is outright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for a generic TD.Oh, and it wigs the ♥♥♥♥ out if I try to play with the mouse while a controller is connected or turned on.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Pure, strategic Tower Defense with a lot of depth thanks to a wealth of play modes, difficulty choices and most importantly tower customization options.  A good sequel to the famed original, 'Defense Grid: The Awakening' which is hailed by many including myself as the best TD ever made.The sequel plays more different than it looks, resource income and scoring is tweaked a bit which has put some off, but is in my opinion an improvement. Boost towers is a great idea which offer extra upgrade options and can be used to adjust towers' line of sight and range.All is not perfect however, and here's a few things that should have been better:- The aliens are poorly designed and it can hard to tell the different types apart at a glance.- Bad sound track.  One track for menues and one during playing is extremely repetitive to listen to.- Ugly low quality FXAA that one has to fiddle with Steam launch command lines to disable.- Leaderboard cheaters is still a thing,  taking some of the drive to replay levels to improve your scores away.- UI is clearly designed for gamepad or tablet navigation.  It is so awkward to navigate with mouse+keys I've actually given up and now play this with a PS3 pad instead.  Big disappointment.- Monetized Steam Workshop for custom maps that is poorly maintained.  Charging money in a retail product for user generated content is a massive slap in the face, this needs to STOP.Outside of that, DG2 is very enjoyable and can offer dozens of hours of well designed tower defense gaming for those that must gold medal various game modes.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												I was a huge fan of the first Defense Grid. I think I have around 170 hours in it last time I checked. I was really looking forward to DG2! I pre-purchased it and played the beta a LOT!After nearly 30 hours of game play in the final release, I feel a little let down. DG2 isn't a bad game by any means but there are a few annoying things about it that keep me from loving it the way I did the first one.First of all, the scoring in the game makes absolutely no sense what-so-ever. Even after all my hours in the game, I have no idea which strategies earn the most points (and I've read all the posts from the developer about the points system). The point system seems very random. The tips the developer has on the DG2 Steam forum are at the very least misleading. The things they claim get your the most points, absolutely do not. The only reason I was able to put up several top 50 scores is nothing more than dumb luck. I have no idea what I did differently that got me more points than other times I played those maps.Ultimately I find the points system extremely frustrating. If I don't know what kinds of things I get rewarded for, how can I possibly come up with strategies that will advance my skill level in the game? I don't want to win with luck. I want to win because I came up with a brilliant plan to score the most points given a known set of measurements of success or failure.Other than that, the game is actually pretty fun. If you're looking for a tower defense game you can play for 15 to 20 hours, DG2 is a great choice (If you already have DG1). If you want a game you can replay over and over, you might want to pass on this one.

												At this point I'm really disappointed by this iteration. It feels like little more than a $10 expansion pack. The visuals are very similar and the mechanics don't seem all that different in the current build. I just don't think the current offering justifies the $25-30 price point.That said, this is very much a Defense Grid game. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												It's Defense Grid again. It's solid tower defense. They've shaken the towers up so that cannons aren't the be-all and end-all of defense, an in fact rather than needing half your maze be ballistic to knock down shields, shields are reworked to the point of almost being irrelevant if you place the disruption tower upgrades appropriately. (As a final insult, level 3 cannon towers are now ugly wheezing bellows. This is not how recoil works, animators. The aliens tend to largely all look the same, too.) Airborne enemies are gone completely, although drop pods make for a tactically interesting replacement, running the maze in reverse.BUT. Big but. Hairline of negative review but.But it's deeply, deeply marred by the godawful AI banter. Everything that was mildly charming and background in the last one is now rubbing in your face like a chinchilla-urine-soaked cheese-grater as a badly-written soap opera unfolds between a half-dozen scenery-chewing unlikable characters. Yes, even he from the first game has become insufferable, and they predictably take his one little quirk and roll a whole stupid plot point around it. Do yourself a favour and put the dialogue volume slider down to zero. Then turn off the subtitles too. The story in this will just kill braincells you need to play the actual game.Oh, and there are persistent unlocks, because boy we've sure gotta be next-gen. I've yet to see if they ruin multiplayer, because that was so ill-designed in the beta it discouraged the other player from buying it.It also feels short when you put it up against the ridiculous amount of content the first one got. As always, wait for a deep sale. This review would certainly be negative at full price.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												I highly recommend this game to those who are new to and familiar with the tower defense genre. I played the first Defense Grid a few years back mainly on Xbox 360 and I feel the sequel compares quite well. Just like the first game, I was hooked into getting the highest medal possible on each of the levels.Found the games story mode to be easier than the first Defense Grid (Probably due to the lack of flying enemies I'd forget to pain attention to in the first game). You can complete levels using a variety of different strategies, at least on easier difficulties.The graphics are nice and I always felt I could get a decent view of the action by rotating/zooming the camera. I ran the game via SteamOS without issue. I used an Xbox 360 controller, which worked fine but feel that the game caters more to keyboard/mouse/desktop setup. Playing from my couch using a 42 inch display I found it challenging to read the text at times (maybe I'm just getting old).I liked how the story played out via audio/text at the beginning of each level while you were playing the game. The story was light and non-intrusive.Fingers crossed for Defense Grid 3.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This is a review based on playing through the first chapter of the campaign missions in Defense Grid 2.The tower designs seem more modern than futuristic this time which is good for me. The gun turrets look more like AA guns now and the cannon turrets look and move vaguely like the mechs in Battlefield 2142. The Medals are back but are purely points based now instead of points and cores like before. I had one core get taken by the aliens in the 2nd map and still got a gold "medal" for it.Other tweaks like the graph showing your score over time with the bronze, silver and gold medals appearing at fixed point values for each map make it easier to tell how you are doing on the map.You now have a Command Shuttle as well and if you click on it you can see your mission stats in real time. The AI from DG: tA is back of course but you also have 2 other AI helping you as well and the banter between them and the other AI you encounter is an interesting change.Being able to upgrade your turrets with mods before starting a mission and the new Booster unit with the Overdrive ability are also cool. For a total cost of 250 energy (50 to deploy and 200 to activate Overdrive) I can see them being used in a few strategies.I will post an update as I play through the rest of the campaign.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Alright, so first of all: I am a big fan of DG 1 and I like DG 2. There. This is a review to dispel some of the wrong and inaccurate information in many negative reviews, that almost made me NOT buy the game!I am currently at Level 6 out of 20, so I have completed 1/4 of the game. This gives me enough information to write a first review. Here are some of the main complaints and what I think about them:1. People complaining that the game is too easy and everyone can beat it on gold and that they can't show off their virtual♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and don't know how to distinguish themselves and increase their score.A: No, the game is NOT too easy. There are 4 difficulty modes. I play on normal. Normal is pretty relaxed so far. There are 2 difficulties above that. I imagine they can be pretty hard. You also have additional challenge modes. You should not get bored unless you're maybe extremely good, but the average john will be challenged with normal alone.Your score is calculated whenever you kill an enemy alien. The score depends on the alien, how much money you have when you kill the alien and how many cores you still possess while killing said alien, while floating cores (the ones not at your core station) count only partially. Only cores that have been taken out of the map do not count at all. Apparently, the scoring system works very similarly to DG 1, but in real time. So this point of criticism is not valid in my opinion.2. People complaining about the resource system and that they have removed interest.A: This is technically not correct. You now receive a fixed income rate per "tick", namely 10, that is true. At the end of a round or every second round (I have to admit I haven't exactly figured that out) you get bonus money based on how much money you have NOT yet spent, meaning the more money you have available the bigger the bonus, i.e. interest. This is explained in the 3rd mission I think. People need to read and pay attention and not provide misinformation (almost every negative review that I read had this issue). So, not only does it pay off to play conservatively in terms of score, but also in terms of money and thus longevity/sustainability. Edit: I forgot to mention that you do no longer gain credits by killing aliens, that's true and it didn't even occur to me...that's bs. That's also why the command tower is gone I think.3. People complaining about how horrible the UI is.A: I have no idea what they are complaining about. People just complain. The UI is perfectly fine. You can get all the required information, it is simple to use etc. You can activate paths, you can show tower impact ranges, building and upgrading towers is as easy or easier than before AND you can play the game with a game pad just as well as with mouse and keyboard, which is brilliant. I personally am a mouse player primarily but I like to use the controller for this, because I can and it’s easy to use. (Update: Just checked and you can also use it in DG 1 but it is slower. Works fine too, however.)4. People complaining about the graphics and style.A: I have to agree here that DG 1 simply had clearer visuals. They tried too much with DG 2. It basically still looks the same, but with a lot more clutter and effects. Aliens and towers are harder to distinguish, although I’d say towers can are still easy to distinguish. Aliens on the other hand feel a bit bland, but mostly I can still see what I’m dealing with. The UI also tells you in the wave information. Personally I wish they had not changed the engine. It didn’t make a lot of sense and probably cost a lot of money. It’s not “ugly”, however.5. People complaining about the performance.A: Personally I couldn’t see any real lag, even with larger alien crowds. Maybe this happens later on. I did notice, however, that the game “seems” a bit sluggish in general.6. People complaining about the sound.A: This is unfortunately absolutely correct. The gun towers simply drown out all other sounds. You could barely hear them in DG 1, but in DG 2 one or 2 gun towers feel like a Manowar concert. You can still hear most other towers if you are in the vicinity, but especially the concussion and the cannon tower are basically silent towers, which is very sad, at least in the cannon tower case, because that “oomph” rocked! I always did hate the concussion tower sound.7.  People complaining about the unimaginative level design.A: Can’t really comment on that. So far the first 5 missions were pretty basic in design. You have to keep in mind, though, that this is not an expansion, but a new game, thus early levels must be simple to have a good learning curve for new players. Will see how it will be later on.8. People complaining about the story and the AI chatter.A: The story is…well, it’s a TD. Who cares, really? I do partially. Fletcher is still great. The others are ok. Before each level you get glimpses into the aliens mind set…this seems “interesting”. So far the chatter has been ok. I think you can also just disable the sound for that? Not sure. Just waiting for the raspberries!9. People complaining about the workshop integration.A: This is actually a pretty strong negative point for the game. Apparently you can “vote” for maps in the workshop, which then become available on the official DG store. I checked and one map seems to cost TWO dollars!!! TWO. Not only is it ridiculous to sell them, but the price is so over the top it is not even funny anymore. If you value community created content, this might be the point for you to NOT purchase the game.Now some general info:-	Aliens: There are a few new ones. Some that regen health. Nothing too interesting. I’m not sure if they took some out. Didn’t look like it, but could be. All in all, pretty boring stuff if you played DG 1.-	Towers: The tower encyclopedia in game does not list ANY new tower at all. In fact, the command tower is now missing…I think that’s the only 1 though.-	Boost blocks: You can build these cheap blocks to create mazes and put your towers on to give them additional effects like increased damage or cloak detect…etc. The concept is “ok”, the execution is…meh. You basically want to build them for every tower, because they only cost 50 credits and without them a tower can simply do 20%!!!!! Less damage. That is huge. Ofc, the upgrade costs money, but still…20% more damage for 250 credits? Still a good deal. Plus you get extended range and fire arcs. I don’t particularly like it. It is a bit clunky.-	Tower bonuses: You unlock bonus abilities for your towers, which you can choose before a mission. For example, my laser tower currently does 15% splash. This is a nice addition, but they could have added more interesting effects. Maybe there will be better ones later, but I somehow doubt it. -	Different commander bonuses: You can now choose a special power at the start of a game. No longer just orbital laser.All in all I would say that DG 2 is a good TD game. IF you have played DG 1 you might find that better in some aspects. It also has more maps to play on. IF you have NOT played DG 1…get DG 1 lol. No, seriously. DG 2 is not a bad game, but DG 1 is better imho. It is not as bad as people make it out to be and I will recommend it, but ONLY at a severely reduced price. Right now, it is 66% off…so only 8 euros or so, which is ok to get a few hours of new tower defense stuff.Overall, however, the “changes” and “additions”, wherever they are, do not warrant a full price…and the community map selling is just plain evil. The creators probably get some small amount for each purchased map, but if you are a map creator and doing this for the money, you’re doing it wrong. I loved creating Star Craft Maps back in the day…it would have never occurred to me to charge anything for that…pffft.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Overall it's really good, but it's more of the same rather than the upgrade I would expect from a sequel. There's a small shuffling of powers, as command towers don't exist but get the same thing from upgrades. The orbital laser can do some new things other than just damage, like slow enemies or buff towers. There are no more flyers, but rather dropships that land at your cores and spawn enemies there. Everything else is pretty much the same, which is disappointing, but since the same is still very good I'm happy with my purchase.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												I bought this game without even thinking for two reasons:1. I loved the first DG, and it's probably the most memorable TD I ever played so far.2. I was going to play the new game in co-op with my friend.Horrible lobby and menu system took me quite some time to figure out how to launch a normal coop campaign game.Then came poor balance. The game was too easy on normal, and way too hard on the next difficulty. Also the level design - I really could not understand why every second level did not even involve any maze building, we just had to place new towers along the road as money came in. On some of the last levels I usually got bored by the end of level so I did not even build towers, I was just talking to my buddy about out stuff and watching monsters get killed.Another problem - connection drop-offs. We got disconnected on every second level, mostly just before finishing it. But since the levels we so easy, I we did not bother and moved to the next one.Last two levels we could not launch at all, because the game was just infinitely loading, no matter what we tried.I am not even going to try look for the fixes for these issues, because the game is not worth it.
